subject: Save-area: Support for Multipart file upload
commitMessage:
Save-area: Support for Multipart file upload

The multipart upload of save-area files is supported by
making use of the mimetic library, which is used to parse
the multipart request.

"multipart/form-data" content-type has been added to the
header that identifies the request body as a
MIME-compatible representation for file upload.

Tested-By:

curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -H
"Content-Type: multipart/form-data" -X POST
https://${bmc}/ibm/v1/Host/ConfigFiles -d $'boundary=
<boundary>\n\n<boundary>\nContent-Disposition=<..>;
name=<filename>\nContent-Type: <Eg:text/plain>\n
<Contents of the file>\n<boundary>\nContent-Disposition=
<..>; name=<filename>\nContent-Type: <Eg:text/plain>\n
<Contents of the file>\n--<boundary>\n'

Signed-off-by: Asmitha Karunanithi <asmitk01@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ibb2b3f3436a70b472154c9af1fc08cabf4ab0f51

So here, the req body is not directly given. Instead, the mimetic obj is constructed using the input iterators.

We are just constructing an object here! And then the method is called recursively from within until the end of the file. So all the parsing work is done only in the method above.


As you mentioned in the comment in line 19, yes there is another way around, by not using temp files.
got it, thanks for the explanation.

createMultiSaveareaFiles

i dont think we should stop if the file in the middle is empty. As long as we get the data with proper format we should continue parsing and creating the files.
If the file name is empty, then we must be returning an error (since we follow "Create All or Create Nothing" way).
fair enough. Fine
remove the commented lines
Ack

I think you can keep adding the filesize when you create files at /tmp/savearea in the method createMultipartFiles(). If you see they are exceeding the max directory size, return false. Then you need not have all these logic in this calling method.

Say, if the file size is 2 MB, and the save area dir size is 9 MB, in this case, this transaction must fail and we should not be creating any files.

The second case, say save area dir size is 9 MB, the size of the files is 1.5 MB, but the same files are already present in the save area directory (which we must be over-written) and in that case, the save area dir count may come within 10 MB (if the size of the common files in /tmp is lesser than that in save area dir) -- Common files basically.

So for this, I hope we must be proceeding with these computations.

Got the logic Asmitha. Thanks.

I think we can have a better way where :
1. Copy the original save area dir to /tmp when you get the PUT or POST. Check if /tmp can contain this or not.
2. Use this /tmp to create files as you are doing now
3. Keep finding duplicate files and replace them at /tmp path itself
4. Keep adding the filesize ; until all the files are received.
5. If  total size fits, then move the /tmp dir to the original dir. If does not fit , discard the /tmp

So as a first step don't start with empty /tmp directory. It can be a duplicate copy of the existing original save area dir

Whats your views on this ?

We can fit the ResourceUpdate logic in this where we can determine if there is any file which is getting updated or newly added.

> 1. Copy the original save area dir to /tmp when you get the PUT or POST. Check if /tmp can contain this or not.

Copy the entire directory content? I would suggest that why we can't do like below.
During parsing of multipart data 
  -> Get the file content and name
  -> If the file is already there then get the size of the file which is already there then get the difference between file exist on the BMC v/s received through this request which could be positive or negative.
  ->  Keep adding the filesize if it is a new file otherwise difference(file size).  
       /var/lib/../save-area directory size + /tmp/save-area directory size(having new files) + difference(could be positive or negative) should be less then the allowed size

I hope my previous patchset does the same. But thought sunitha's suggestion would reduce the number of computations involved.

> Copy the entire directory content? I would suggest that why we can't do like below.

Ack.

I think i can revert back my changes to the previous patchset.
misplaced ? comment should go to line 281
Ack
Please add a comment in your commit about how much this adds to the binary size of bmcweb.
This is a crazy size to allow by default.
This code doesn't use global scoped using, and definitely not global scoped "using namespace".  Please fix.
nit: declare as constexpr const to match the above definitions.
You're checking capacity here.  I suspect you meant to check size().  capacity can be much greater than size.
"huge" is a really bad way to describe an error.  Please reword.

This goes against one of the primary security design goals of bmcweb, in that it writes a file from a a user controlled parameter.  Please amend your design to not do this, and properly sanitize the user-driven strings.
This variable, despite being passed into your recursive function, doesn't look like it's used for anything.  Please refactor and remove.

??????  You're adding Content-Type, as a header, do the body of the request, although it's not clear why.  Presumably you should be using the header().contentType() api for this, instead of adding it to the payload (and moving the payload out of the request object).

I see no checking of errors here.

Also, please use the iterator based MimeEntity constructor instead of the stream based constructor, as you know the final size, and will make the parsing faster.

Looking at it again, the load() API might be what you really want here.
Missing locks if this API is called from multiple callers.
Certainly you don't actually want std::uintmax_t here.  Pick an integer size that fits your application.  I'm guessing in a lot of these cases you want size_t.
see above about uintmax_t.  I'm guessing here you want to use size_t, as that contains the limit of the containers you're using.
You create a vector here, then you attempt to use it like a linear scanning map on line 235.  Why not just make it an unordered map (or in this case, probably a boost::container::flat_map)
As part of the mime payload, you know what files were written.  You should build this map as part of creating the files, not by iterating the directory after the fact.
I suspect this (soon to be map) should simply contain a std::filesystem::path, as that's what you're storing here.
patchFile is going to be taken by copy here.  I'm guessing that's not what you want.
Overflow safety error here.  See above about picking appropriate types.  These types of unsafe conversions happen in a number of places.  I will comment only here.

You are doing this check AFTER you've written all the files to tmp.  For safety, this check needs to be done while you're operating, so the files on disk aren't allowed to be larger than the allowed.

Also, won't this leak, and leave the files in tmp?
Why are you pulling the data into a temp, then copying it into place?  Just write it in the right place?
You are using a redfish error code in a non-redfish API.  Please fix.
You have forgotten about concurrency here.  What if 2 users/connections attempt to save to the same location at once.  This is very likely to overwrite someone elses file.  Please fix.
Not clear why these were added.  ostream is an RAII type, and will close when it leaves scope?
Please don't invent your own router here.  There is already a URL router that handles everything you've done here.  Please use it.

This should be using some form of RAII response type (like AsyncResp).

The res.end() pattern has been going away for some time now, as it was too difficult to get right.
Possible leak.  If this falls through to the end, the response will never complete.

Don't do it this way.  Register 2 handlers, one for POST and one for GET, and have them call the correct callbacks appropriately.  It saves on having to do the GET/POST/PATCH branch multiple times.  Presumably you would need different permissions on the POST handler than you do the GET handler.
